entry.title: Tourists in France
entry.content:
There's a misconception that the French are rude...

â€¦ but if I were French I donâ€™t think I could stand the tourists.

Never have I been in a another country where tourists so readily disregard a countryâ€™s native tongue. During a dinner at a brasserie by the TrocadÃ©ro in Paris I witnessed the typical American tourist and I could feel nothing but embarrassment.

â€œYou got any bourbon?â€ He drawled in lazy English as the waiter looked baffled.

â€œYou know, BURR-BUN WISS-KEY!â€

He made an off-hand comment about the French people as he shooed away the poor waiter with his wine-list. It felt like such a stark contrast in experiences as I enjoyed a superb meal that was made with pride. The steak was beautifully seared and basted; the fries, hand-cut and cooked to perfection. Even the humble side salad was composed of the freshest butter lettuce Iâ€™ve ever eaten. The waiter (who was patient with my garbage French) recommended the best pairing of wine that I still dream about to this dayâ€“ a red Brouilly ğŸ¥°

Along the northern coast lies a small picturesque town called Ã‰tretat. Kelsie and I picked a small seafood restaurant for dinner and were sat next to another tourist couple. At this point of the trip we had been in France for a little over a week, and I could speak enough French to not rely on English at all in a restaurantâ€“ even if I had to count on my fingers to remember cinq is five ğŸ˜… As I enjoyed my delicious sole meuniÃ¨re, our tourist neighbors took out their phone for the waitress and were insistently pointing to a picture of a lobster. Needless to say, the waitress was incredibly confusedâ€“ it wasnâ€™t on the menu or even remotely native to the area.

I suppose travel only broadens the mind insofar as one allows him/herself to be open to anotherâ€™s culture.
entry.summary: There's a misconception that the French are rude...

entry.title: History of Music Taste (abridged)
entry.content:
When it comes to music, I've been pretty "on the spectrum"...

Before the age of 7 I compulsively listened to my parentâ€™s Mannheim Steamroller album and the Rusted Root song â€œSend Me on My Wayâ€. This obsession with specific songs peaked when I heard Griegâ€™s â€œIn the Hall of the Mountain Kingâ€ where I probably listened to it ten times a day for a couple of months. Trent Reznor and Atticus Rossâ€™ rendition for The Social Network soundtrack is also ğŸ‘ŒI still enjoy instrumental music a lot these days. Patrick Oâ€™Hearnâ€™s â€œBeyond this Momentâ€ and Erik WÃ¸lloâ€™s â€œSedonaâ€ are just my vibe.

After a pretty intense Weird Al stage, my first â€œrealâ€ album was Franz Ferdinandâ€™s self-titled. Iâ€™m notoriously bad at memorizing lyrics, but I listened to this album so much that I know the words not only to their hit â€œTake Me Outâ€, but to the entire album.

For better or worse, my teenage years consisted of entirely indie musicâ€“ whatever the hell that means. Modest Mouse was tops though. â€œLounge (Closing Time)â€ and â€œSpitting Venomâ€ are two of my faves.

My twenties consisted of a lot of hip-hop, of far more artists than I can name. What an absolutely inventive and varied genre of music. If I had to pick some of my favorites off the top of my head they would be â€œExhibit Aâ€ by Jay Electronica and Kanye Westâ€™s My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy album.

At some point during this time I had a couple of transformational music experiences:

  1. Hearing this guyâ€™s acoustic cover of The White Stripeâ€™s â€œBall and Biscuitâ€ which got me into the blues.
  2. Going to a Steel Panther and Judas Priest concert with â€œTurkeyâ€ and Ashlee which opened my eyes and ears to glorious metal ğŸ¤˜ As I enter my thirties those two genres are what really resonate with me. They are both very rhythm-centric and many songs are played in the best key (E). So many great riffs were written in Eâ€¦
entry.summary: When it comes to music, I've been pretty "on the spectrum"...
